title: How to Remove a Stamp from Its Envelope

steps.title: Decide to remove or keep the stamp on the paper.
steps.content: Decide to remove or keep the stamp on the paper. Some stamps are more valuable if they are kept on the envelope. An old stamp may be worth a few dollars by itself but may be worth many times that in the historical context of the envelope that bears it. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Cut stamps off the corner of the envelope with some scissors.
steps.content: Cut stamps off the corner of the envelope with some scissors. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Place the cut corner in bowl of warm water and wait 10+ minutes.
steps.content: Place the cut corner in bowl of warm water and wait 10+ minutes. [3] X Research source Apply cold water if you are worried the ink might run. In the past, some stamps were manufactured so soaking would ruin the stamp; this prevented people from illegally reusing them on new mail.

steps.title: Most of the stamps will float off, so put them on the blotter of paper towels face down.
steps.content: Most of the stamps will float off, so put them on the blotter of paper towels face down. Do this carefully so the stamps do not tear or crease. [4] X Research source Some stamps require coaxing to come off the paper, especially the newer "peel and stick" versions.

steps.title: Put the cookie sheet of stamps in a dry place (such as the unheated oven) overnight.
steps.content: Put the cookie sheet of stamps in a dry place (such as the unheated oven) overnight.

steps.title: Place the now dry (and maybe a bit curled) stamps flat between the pages of a large book and weigh them down if necessary.
steps.content: Place the now dry (and maybe a bit curled) stamps flat between the pages of a large book and weigh them down if necessary.

steps.title: Leave them for 3 weeks to be flat for handling and sorting into your collection, or for later use.
steps.content: Leave them for 3 weeks to be flat for handling and sorting into your collection, or for later use.

steps.title: Empty envelope.
steps.content: Empty envelope. Remove the contents of the envelope.

steps.title: Place in microwave.
steps.content: Place in microwave. This is only to melt the adhesive from the stamp. [5] X Research source >1000 watt- Microwave for around 10 seconds 700-950 watt- Microwave for around 15-20 seconds

steps.title: Peel.
steps.content: Peel. Peel off the stamp from the envelope. If it does not come off easily, repeat step 2.

steps.title: Tape or glue.
steps.content: Tape or glue. The adhesive from the stamp is no longer effective. It will require you to use tape or glue to keep the stamp on the new envelope.

steps.title: Insert your nails.
steps.content: Insert your nails. Place your nails under the stamp. Use 2 fingers. Use your nails to pull up the stamp a little.

steps.title: Pull.
steps.content: Pull. Use your finger to pull the stamp up. Pull slowly and carefully. You can rip the stamp or envelope if you do not pull carefully.

steps.title: Tape or glue.
steps.content: Tape or glue. By peeling a small amount of paper from the envelope can stick to the adhesive.
